content.body: annevk Domenic i am thinking about multi-select for selectlist (i dont plan on formally proposing this for a very long time), and im wondering if it should have a multiple attribute or a have a distinct tag name. i kind of like having a separate tag name more because then we dont have to handle changes between the single and multiple, but what do yall think? were <select multiple> and <input type> bad ideas?

content.body: this has been briefly discussed in openui but with no recent updates: https://github.com/openui/open-ui/issues/447

jarhar:

> were "select multiple" and "input type" bad ideas?

Yes, IMHO. At least from the perspective of developer ergonomics. Especially in the case of ‚Äùinput type‚Äù, smuggling 20 different logical elements with different presentations/UI/behavior into one element has created very significant costs that would have been unnecessary otherwise. It's made it more difficult to document, and more difficult to do conformance checking for, more difficult to explain to  developers when they run into problems (for example, developers coming to Stack Overflow with questions, and other people trying to help answer them).

* jarhar:  were "select multiple" and "input type" bad ideas?

Yes, IMHO. At least from the perspective of developer ergonomics. Especially in the case of ‚Äùinput type‚Äù, smuggling 20 different logical elements with different presentations/UI/behavior into one element has created very significant costs that would have been unnecessary otherwise. It's made it more difficult to document, and more difficult to do conformance checking for, more difficult to explain to  developers when they run into problems (for example, developers coming to Stack Overflow with questions, and other people trying to help answer them).

content.body: Heh, we're still evaluating `<selectlist>`. üòÖ
content.formatted_body: Heh, we're still evaluating <selectlist>. üòÖ

content.body:
I think what I'd look at is how much branching you would need to do and how much shared code there ends up being between the two features. And how difficult it would be to add new features if they were separate elements.

And while it's probably correct that we'd do `<input>` differently today, the way it was designed has a number of benefits we still benefit from today. It has made it much easier to introduce new input controls, such as `type=email`. Or soon `<input type=checkbox switch>`.
content.formatted_body:
I think what I'd look at is how much branching you would need to do and how much shared code there ends up being between the two features. And how difficult it would be to add new features if they were separate elements.

And while it's probably correct that we'd do <input> differently today, the way it was designed has a number of benefits we still benefit from today. It has made it much easier to introduce new input controls, such as type=email. Or soon <input type=checkbox switch>.

content.body: I would prefer separate elements.
I had forgotten why making progress on `<input type=email>` was difficult, but now it's very clear again unfortunately
content.formatted_body: I had forgotten why making progress on <input type=email> was difficult, but now it's very clear again unfortunately

content.body: Is it right that a bubbling+composed event with a relatedTarget stops bubbling when it hits the shadowroot? Shouldn't it retarget the relatedTarget to the host?

```
y = $0.attachShadow({mode:'open'})
y.append(document.createElement('button'))
x = y.querySelector('button')
x.addEventListener('focusin', console.log)
y.addEventListener('focusin', console.log)
$0.addEventListener('focusin', console.log)
x.dispatchEvent(new FocusEvent('focusin', { relatedTarget: x, bubbles: true, composed: true }))
```

I only get 2 `console.logs` when I expected 3
content.formatted_body:
y = $0.attachShadow({mode:'open'})
y.append(document.createElement('button'))
x = y.querySelector('button')
x.addEventListener('focusin', console.log)
y.addEventListener('focusin', console.log)
$0.addEventListener('focusin', console.log)
x.dispatchEvent(new FocusEvent('focusin', { relatedTarget: x, bubbles: true, composed: true }))

I only get 2 console.logs when I expected 3

content.body: If I `s/FocusEvent/Event` I get 3.
content.formatted_body: If I s/FocusEvent/Event I get 3.

content.body: Noam Rosenthal: activateAfter makes me think it's no different from activationTimeout
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: activateAfter makes me think it's no different from activationTimeout

content.body: Noam Rosenthal: as in, setTimeout runs after x seconds
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: as in, setTimeout runs after x seconds

content.body: Noam Rosenthal: before you talked about a deadline, which made me think that if you passed x, running at x-1 would be okay, but x+1 would not be; doesn't that mean "before"? Whereas for "after" x+1 would be fine.
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: before you talked about a deadline, which made me think that if you passed x, running at x-1 would be okay, but x+1 would not be; doesn't that mean "before"? Whereas for "after" x+1 would be fine.

content.body: annevk: both are fine, but for different reasons. The timeout duration is like a preference. The UA would activate before the timeout in case of termination or some such, and after the activation timeout for throttling/batching
content.formatted_body: annevk: both are fine, but for different reasons. The timeout duration is like a preference. The UA would activate before the timeout in case of termination or some such, and after the activation timeout for throttling/batching

content.body: The word "timeout" is maybe confusing because it's the opposite of the abort signal's timeout
Yea `activateAfter` means the same thing but it's clear it's a timeout *until* activation rather than "A timeout after which activation expires" or something like that
content.formatted_body: Yea activateAfter means the same thing but it's clear it's a timeout until activation rather than "A timeout after which activation expires" or something like that

content.body: Same; multi-select is related to single-select, but wants a fairly distinct UI. (Even the existing godawful UI is quite distinct between the two states.)
So yeah, multiple elements.
